summary: Tab is a specialized Cursor model for autocompletion. It can modify multiple lines at once, add import statements, jump within and across files, and learns from your acceptance patterns.
key_takeaways: Accept suggestions with Tab, reject with Escape, or accept word-by-word with Cmd+Arrow Right.
Tab predicts your next editing location and can jump across files.
Auto-import automatically adds import statements in TypeScript and Python.
Tab works in Go to Definition peek views for modifying function signatures.

questions.question: How do you accept Tab suggestions word-by-word instead of all at once?
questions.explanation: Press Cmd+Arrow Right (or Ctrl+Right on Windows) to accept one word at a time. This is called Partial Accepts and can be enabled in Cursor Settings â†’ Tab.

questions.question: How does Tab display suggestions for modifying existing code versus adding new code?

options.text: New code appears as ghost text, modifications appear as a diff popup
Both appear in a separate panel

questions.explanation: When adding text, completions appear as semi-opaque ghost text inline. When modifying existing code, Tab shows a diff popup to the right of your current line.

questions.question: What should you check if auto-import isn't working for TypeScript?

options.text: Check if Tab is enabled in settings
Ensure the project has the right language server and the import appears in Quick Fix (Cmd+.) suggestions

questions.explanation: If auto-import isn't working, ensure your project has the right language server or extensions, and test with Cmd+. to check if the import appears in Quick Fix suggestions.
